answers.answer: I do not have the same story as you but I think most pg women at some point stress about the extra weight no matter how much or how little they have gained.  I have gained 14 (as of last dr visit maybe more like 20 after today's visit).  I am now almost 36 weeks pg and I am having issues with the reality of this.  I think something is going to happen to my baby too.  I just can't seem to get it in my head that this is going to happen.  Seems so unreal to me.  I don't see myself going thru labor or even having the baby afterwards.  Just seems so unreal.  However, it is going to happen.  Don't worry about the way you look.  Pg women are beautiful.  Some gain alot and some gain alittle.  All you can do is try to eat healthy (which I find harder and harder to do nearing the end of this).  Good luck to you and your baby!

Firstly, congrats on yuor pg!! You have ben given a miracle, and Im sure it totally sucks and makes you feel guilty to have a neg. emotions connected to it.  However, what yu are ffeling is totally normal.  Your body is not in your control and it doesnt look like you think it should.  It is completely normal that you are depresssed.  Add to that the rest regimine, and you have a recipe for unhappiness.  Since you were able to lose all that weight to begin with, I am sure you willhave no prob. losing it again.  Also, as this is your first pg you wont know this, but a lot of the weight is water weight from bloating and will be lst with no effort throught sweat and urine and nursing.  The recomended weight gain is 35 lbs, and youve gained 50.  After the first few months when the water weight goes away, you will be left with aprox. 15 lbs. to lose - no big deal.  Try to keep this in mind now.  You are at 30 wqks allready, and weight gain usually slows then, and usually completely sdtops at 36 weeks.  Im not sure how your gest. diabetes affects weight gain, but Im sure that is a factor too.  Try to concentrate on the baby and plan the nursery etc. and watch a lot of funny movies.  If your dr. allows it, try to get out every day.  It helps a lot.  And remember that yuo have a support group here any time you need us!! (((HUGS)))

After 13 years of being told you can't have a baby, your pg is certain to be an emotional roller coaster.  I have never known anything to affect me emotionally the way infertility has, and I think it takes more than getting pregnant to heal the years of pain, depression and frustration it causes.  Rejoice in your pregnancy and your pregnant body. Make sure that you share your feelings and reach out for help after you deliver too, in case you have the baby blues.I have friends who weighed in under 130 pounds pre-pregnancy, gained minimal weight and still got gestational diabetes, kidney stones, etc...that can happen to anyone, even those who take great care of themselves, which it sounds like you are doing.Take care and enjoy your pregnancy.  You lost all of that weight before -- you can do it again!  :)

question: Has anyone felt depressed since they became pregnant? Here is my story. I have been with my husband for 14 years. WE were told that we could not not have children the entire time (I have pcos). Well about 2 years ago i put myself on a diet and lost 91 pounds!!! Then in October of 2005 I had a miscarriage (didn't even know I was pregnant). It was a huge blow to my heart because after being told I couldnt have a baby for 13 years I lose it. Well just 2 months later I find out I am pregnant again, put on progesterone pills and told not to do house work or anything like that (also quit smoking the day I found out I was pregnant). Well I am no 30 weeks along, found out I have gull stones and gestational diabetes and have put on 55 pounds. I hate myself everytime I look in a mirror and feel so sad all the time. I guess in my head something is going to happen where I dont have my baby. I feel ugly and sad and have never felt this way before. I am sooooo thankful to final be pregnant, so why do I feel so sad in my heart??
title: Depression
